nodes.text: Machine learning classifiers applied to CT image data can enable accurate early detection of lung cancer, with SVM expected to outperform KNN and Random Forest
Data used: 500 CT images sampled from the LIDC-IDRI dataset, supplemented by small sample sets from AHRC and AIMS for validation

Image preprocessing pipeline included resizing 512x512x3 to 256x, contrast enhancement (CLAHE), Wiener filtering, adaptive Gaussian filtering, Gaussian and Gabor filtering, normalization and segmentation using thresholding and marker-controlled watershed
Classifiers evaluated: K-Nearest Neighbors using Euclidean distance, Support Vector Machine maximizing class margin, and Random Forest ensemble of decision trees with bootstrap sampling
Training and evaluation protocol: 70% of images used for training, 30% for testing, 5-fold cross validation applied for performance estimation

Labels: binary setup with abnormal images showing Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC) in various stages versus normal images without radiological abnormalities; radiologist supervision used for validation
Feature extraction and segmentation produced inputs for classifiers after preprocessing and resizing; representative CT samples shown to illustrate data quality
SVM achieved average accuracy 95.06% with average true positive rate 0.99, average false positive rate 0.26, average precision 0.95, average F1-score 0.98 using 5-fold cross validation
KNN achieved average accuracy 86.89% with average true positive rate 0.98, average false positive rate 0.38, average precision 0.84, average F1-score 0.91 using 5-fold cross validation
Random Forest achieved average accuracy 81.96% with average true positive rate 0.98, average false positive rate 0.48, average precision 0.78, average F1-score 0.87 using 5-fold cross validation
Comparative claim: SVM outperformed KNN and Random Forest on this dataset and preprocessing pipeline, attributed to SVM handling complex decision boundaries and high-dimensional features
External comparison: proposed SVM model accuracy 95.05% exceeds reported accuracies of selected prior works (examples: Murphy 84.00%, Messay 82.66%, Gomathi 76.90%, Kumer 86.00%)
Conclusion: The proposed image-processing pipeline combined with SVM classification can detect lung cancer with high accuracy and may aid early diagnosis and improved patient outcomes
Validation: Small hospital sample sets from AHRC and AIMS were used under radiologist supervision to validate model outputs and support generalizability claims

Limitations and future work: study used a limited sample of 500 images and small local validation sets; authors propose expanding to larger, more diverse datasets to improve reliability and generalization
